channel.title: Differential Equation & Laplaces on
channel.description: Recent content in Differential Equation & Laplaces on

item.title: Differential Equation & Laplace
item.description: > Dashboard Lesson 1 Lesson 2 Lesson 3 Lesson 4 Lesson 5 Lesson 6 Lesson 7 WIP - Lesson 7

item.title: Lesson 1
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Equation An equation is an expression of a relationship between quantities, also called variables or unknowns.

item.title: Lesson 2
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Serparating variables A differential equation has two variables. For some differential equations it is possible to separate the variables: on the left-hand-side there is just the dependent and on the right-hand-side just the independent variable.

item.title: Lesson 3
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Direction field A differential equation can be visualised in a sol called direction field.

item.title: Lesson 4
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Linear first-order homogenous differential equations General form: $\frac{dx}{dt} + p(t)\cdot x = 0$

item.title: Lesson 5
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Non homogenous differential equation $$\frac{dx}{dt} + p(t)\cdot x = r(t)$$ If $r(t) \neq 0$ then this linear differential equation is not homogenous.

item.title: Lesson 6
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Linear higher-order differential equations General form: $$a_{n} \frac{d^{n}x}{dt^{x}} + a_{n-1} \frac{d^{n-1}x}{dt^{n-1}}+\cdots + a_{1}\frac{dx}{dt}+a_{0}x = r(t)$$ if $r(t) = 0$ then the differential equation is homogeneous.

item.title: Lesson 7
item.description: > Dashboard > Differential Equation & Laplace Boundary values If we want to solve a specific second-order differential equation, two boundary values are necessary.
